key_points: Social media users are misleadingly comparing the Colonial Pipeline hack to unfounded election fraud claims, suggesting if one can be hacked, so can the other.
The Colonial Pipeline was hit by a ransomware attack on May 7, affecting its IT systems and halting operations.
Fact check reveals these claims are misleading; investigations have found no evidence of interference in the November 2020 election.
Ransomware attacks encrypt data to extort ransom, often targeting corporations and hospitals.
The FBI identified software from the cybercrime group DarkSide as responsible for the Colonial Pipeline attack.
Kevin Feeney, a spokesperson for Colonial Pipeline, highlighted the company's stringent IT and operational technology segmentation policies.
Posts connecting the pipeline hack to voting machine vulnerabilities build on baseless 2020 election fraud claims.
Will Adler from the Center for Democracy & Technology states the comparison is misleading and that U.S. voting systems are not vulnerable on a large scale.
Election security measures and the decentralized nature of U.S. elections prevent such cyberattacks from impacting election outcomes.
Dominion Voting Systems and other authorities have consistently refuted claims of election infrastructure hacking in the 2020 election.
spokespersons: Will Adler (senior technologist for elections and democracy, Center for Democracy & Technology)
